text: I would say every single time the voice in your head is wrong. That critical voice in your head. To be specific, I'm talking about the voice in your head that is critical and repeats. There's the voice that says the same thing over and over again. You got to work out more, you got to work out more, you got to work out more. Whatever that is, it's always wrong, and that doesn't mean there isn't truth to what it says, but it's incorrect.
speaker: Joe Hudson
context: Lenny asks Joe about his insight that the voice in your head is often wrong and contradictory. Joe explains that the critical, repetitive voice in your head - the one that constantly tells you things like "you should work out more" - is always wrong, even when there might be some truth to what it's saying. He argues that this voice isn't actually helping you be productive, despite what most people believe.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 머릿속 그 목소리는 매번 틀려요. 그 비판적인 목소리요. 구체적으로 말하면 비판적이고 같은 말을 계속 반복하는 바로 그 목소리를 말하는 거예요. '더 운동해야 해, 더 운동해야 해…'처럼요. 그게 무엇이든 항상 틀려요. 물론 그 말에 진실이 섞여 있을 수는 있지만, 결국엔 옳지 않아요.
text_zh: 我跟你说，脑子里那个声音，十有八九都是错的。就是那个老爱挑毛病的声音。具体来说，我说的是你脑子里那个既爱批评又老是重复的声音。就是那种翻来覆去说同一件事的声音——你得多锻炼，你得多锻炼，你得多锻炼。不管它说什么，基本都是错的。这不是说它说的完全没道理，但它的方式肯定是不对的。
text_es: Yo diría que esa voz en tu cabeza siempre está equivocada. Esa voz crítica que tienes ahí arriba. Para ser específico, me refiero a esa voz en tu cabeza que es crítica y que se repite como disco rayado. Es esa voz que te dice lo mismo una y otra y otra vez. "Tienes que hacer más ejercicio, tienes que hacer más ejercicio, tienes que hacer más ejercicio." Sea lo que sea, siempre está mal, y eso no significa que no haya algo de verdad en lo que dice, pero su enfoque está equivocado.
key_sentence: The critical voice in your head is always wrong and repeats itself.

text: I think the best way to work with the voice in the head is to pick an experiment every day and respond to the voice in the head in a new way every day. One of my favorite responses is, "Oh, I see that you're really scared. Don't worry. I'm right here with you. I got you."
speaker: Joe Hudson
context: Lenny asks Joe how to practically work with the critical voice in your head. Joe explains that instead of trying to stop or control this voice, you should change how you relate to it. He recommends taking an experimental approach where you respond to the critical voice differently each day, treating it like a scared child rather than an authority figure.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 머릿속의 목소리와 가장 잘 일하는 방법은 매일 하나씩 실험을 골라 그 목소리에 매일 새로운 방식으로 반응해 보는 거예요. 제가 좋아하는 반응 중 하나는 "아, 네가 정말 무서워하구나. 괜찮아요. 내가 여기 같이 있어요. 내가 지켜줄게요."예요.
text_zh: 我觉得对付脑子里那个声音最好的办法，就是每天都试试新招，每天都用不同的方式去回应它。我最喜欢的回应方式是："哦，我看出来你挺害怕的。别担心，我就在这儿陪着你呢，有我在。"
text_es: Creo que la mejor manera de manejar esa voz en la cabeza es elegir un experimento cada día y responderle de una forma nueva cada día. Una de mis respuestas favoritas es: "Ah, veo que tienes mucho miedo. Tranquila. Estoy aquí contigo. Te tengo cubierta."
key_sentence: Pick an experiment daily to respond to the voice in your head.

text: It's such an important tool for productivity. If you say, I'm going to figure out how to enjoy what I do 10% more and you succeed, you are 10% more efficient. Not only that, usually, the quality is going to get a lot better too.
speaker: Joe Hudson
context: Lenny asks Joe about his focus on helping people feel joy. Joe explains that enjoyment isn't just about feeling good - it's actually a powerful productivity tool. He argues that if you can learn to enjoy what you're doing even 10% more, you become 10% more efficient and the quality of your work improves significantly.
text_ko: 정말 생산성(productivity)을 높이는 중요한 도구예요. ‘내가 하는 일을 10% 더 즐기게 만드는 방법을 찾아볼 거야’라고 생각해서 실제로 그렇게 된다면 10% 더 효율적으로 일하게 돼요. 게다가 보통 일의 품질도 훨씬 좋아져요.
text_zh: 这真的是提高工作效率的重要手段。你要是能想办法让自己对工作多享受个10%，那你的效率就能提升10%。不仅如此，通常工作质量也会大幅提升。
text_es: Es una herramienta clave para la productividad. Si te dices, voy a buscar la manera de disfrutar 10% más lo que hago y lo logras, vas a ser 10% más eficiente. Y no solo eso, por lo general la calidad también va a mejorar muchísimo.
key_sentence: Enjoying what you do 10% more is a tool for productivity.

text: Whatever emotion that you're trying to avoid, you are inviting into your life in exactly the way that you're trying to avoid it.
speaker: Joe Hudson
context: Lenny asks Joe what is holding people back from success and living the life they want. Joe identifies emotions that people are not sitting with, feeling, or expressing as a major factor. He explains a counterintuitive principle: when you try to avoid feeling a particular emotion, you actually end up experiencing more of that exact emotion in your life.
text_ko: 피하려고 애쓰는 감정일수록, 오히려 그걸 피하려는 바로 그 방식대로 삶에 초대하고 있어요.
text_zh: 你越想逃避什么情绪，它就越会以你最不想要的方式出现在你生活里。
text_es: Cualquier emoción que trates de evitar, la estás invitando a tu vida justo de la manera en que intentas evitarla.
key_sentence: Avoided emotions are inviting into your life in exactly the way you resist.

text: A lot of the people in my circles may have spent hundreds of millions of dollars to try to arrange a life that they enjoy, and it doesn't fucking work.
speaker: Joe Hudson
context: Joe is explaining why learning to enjoy what you're currently doing is more powerful than trying to arrange your external circumstances for enjoyment. He notes that many wealthy people he coaches have spent enormous amounts of money trying to create an enjoyable life through external means - buying jets, islands, and luxury items - but this approach fundamentally fails to create lasting satisfaction.
text_ko: 제 주변 사람들 중 많은 분들이 자기들이 즐길 수 있는 삶을 만들기 위해 수억 달러를 썼을 수도 있는데, 그게 진짜 아무 소용이 없더라고요.
text_zh: 我身边很多人砸了几个亿想要打造自己理想的生活，结果根本不管用。
text_es: Muchos de la gente en mi entorno han gastado cientos de millones de dólares tratando de armar una vida que les guste, y no funciona para nada.
key_sentence: Arranging a life often doesn't fucking work, despite spending millions.

text: I would do seven minutes, no less than seven minutes. You can do more than seven minutes. Seven minutes of gratitude with another person every day. It has to be feeling the gratitude and then seeing what comes out of your mouth when you're coming from the felt sense of gratitude and doing it back and forth.
speaker: Joe Hudson
context: Lenny asks Joe for one practical thing everyone can try to become better and more successful. Joe recommends a specific daily gratitude practice: spending exactly seven minutes sharing gratitude back and forth with another person, but emphasizing that it must come from actually feeling the emotion of gratitude in your body, not just intellectual thoughts about what you're grateful for.
text_ko: 저라면 7분은 꼭 하겠어요. 7분보다 짧으면 안 되고, 더 해도 좋아요. 매일 다른 사람과 함께하는 7분간의 감사 시간이요. 중요한 건 감사하는 마음을 진짜로 느끼고, 그 체감되는 감사(felt sense)에서 우러나오는 말을 서로 주고받아 보는 거예요.
text_zh: 我建议每天至少七分钟，不能少于七分钟。你可以做得更久一点。每天和另一个人做七分钟的感恩练习。关键是要真正感受到那种感激之情，然后看看当你发自内心感恩的时候会说出什么话，你们俩就这样互相分享。
text_es: Yo haría siete minutos, no menos de siete minutos. Puedes hacer más de siete minutos si quieres. Siete minutos de gratitud con otra persona todos los días. Tiene que ser sintiendo realmente la gratitud y luego viendo qué sale de tu boca cuando vienes desde esa sensación genuina de agradecimiento, haciéndolo de ida y vuelta entre los dos.
key_sentence: Practice seven minutes of gratitude back and forth with another person.

text: Joy is the matriarch of a family of emotions and she won't come into a house where her children aren't welcome. A very joyful life is a life where all the other emotions are deeply welcomed, not accepted, not non-judgmentally aware of.
speaker: Joe Hudson
context: Lenny asks Joe about the difference between non-judgmental awareness of emotions (from meditation practices) and Joe's approach to working with emotions. Joe shares his famous metaphor about joy being like the matriarch of a family - she won't visit a home where her children (other emotions) aren't truly welcome. He emphasizes that emotions need to be welcomed and loved, not just tolerated or observed neutrally.
text_ko: 기쁨은 감정들의 어머니 같은 존재예요. 그 감정들이 환영받지 못하는 집에는 기쁨이 들어오지 않아요. 진정으로 기쁨이 넘치는 삶은 다른 모든 감정들을 단순히 받아들이거나 판단하지 않는 정도로 알아주는 게 아니라, 깊이 마음으로 환영하는 삶이에요.
text_zh: 快乐就像是情绪大家庭里的老大，如果她的孩子们在这个家里不受欢迎，她是不会进门的。真正快乐的人生，就是要发自内心地拥抱所有其他的情绪，不是简单地接受，也不是那种无所谓的态度。
text_es: La alegría es como la matriarca de toda la familia de emociones, y no va a entrar a una casa donde sus hijos no sean bienvenidos. Una vida realmente plena es aquella donde todas las demás emociones son profundamente bienvenidas, no solo aceptadas o reconocidas sin más.
key_sentence: Joy is the matriarch of a family of emotions, welcomed deeply in life.
